head.title: No Quick Fixes On Welfare Reform

hedline.hl1: No Quick Fixes On Welfare Reform

block.p: Re ''Bold Effort Leaves Much Unchanged for the Poor'' (front page, Dec. 30): Welfare reform is no panacea. After 35 years of handouts and helping hands, the poor are faced with the same intractable dilemma: With or without work, they still can't make ends meet. That's because as earned income rises, welfare benefits are taken away.

Re ''Bold Effort Leaves Much Unchanged for the Poor'' (front page, Dec. 30): Welfare reform is no panacea. After 35 years of handouts and helping hands, the poor are faced with the same intractable dilemma: With or without work, they still can't make ends meet. That's because as earned income rises, welfare benefits are taken away.

Recognizing that welfare is the problem, there's a simple solution. Close down our social programs and return the savings to the people. Our studies have shown that there is enough money in the federal budget to provide a taxable annual rebate of $4,000 per adult and $2,000 per child. That's enough to turn even the lowest wage into a living wage while providing real tax relief for the middle class.
The writer is a senior research associate at the Institute for Socioeconomic Studies.
